stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream refining a new "paper-airplane" transportation gimmick and a rubber-band slingshot for Course 14, while briefly showing the nearly finished demo build running on real N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is coding a paper-airplane object that carries Mario; he’s iterating on formulas that combine forward velocity, gravity, sine of pitch and friction so the plane swoops realistically, loses speed while climbing, regains it while diving, and finally lands on a cardboard pyramid.
development_findings.quote: We just need to fudge the equations in a way that we get the result we want.

development_findings.summary: To shorten iteration time he moved the airplane’s spawn point and added on-stream logging of forward velocity and pitch to locate runaway values.
A Fast64 export quirk cut off the first animation frame of the rubber-band slingshot; adding a keyframe before frame 0 or duplicating the transform fixes the issue.
development_findings.quote: The first animation frame wasn't exporting because there's a smart animation range feature that cuts out all the frames until the first one we have a keyframe on.

development_findings.summary: He finished the breakable paper-target mechanic off-stream; targets now shatter when hit by Mario’s face animation.

The public demo is ‘all done’; Kaze fixed N64-only bugs (AA coverage lines, Z-ordering), added an option to toggle anti-aliasing and verified ~50–60 FPS on console using the new F3DX3 microcode and occlusion planes.
development_findings.quote: My game now is RSP-bottlenecked, so F3DX3 and the triangle strips really help.

development_findings.summary: Course 14 is a diorama with four biomes (desert, Styrofoam mountains, castle, grasslands); final name may be "Handmade Heights."
He’s recording per-course design-analysis videos before releasing a remix so future revisions are easier.
development_findings.quote: I want to have the videos done before the remix exists—it's more time-efficient that way and we care about time efficiency here.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mocks viewers who say they lack time: school is only six hours; you still have ten hours left.
context_findings.quote: I've always been a hater for people that are like, 'I can't work on my R64 because I have school.' You have all the time you want, you're just being a pussy.

context_findings.summary: He’s skeptical of AI coding help; says current models are "horrendous" for his kind of low-level work.
context_findings.quote: AI used to be better at programming, but at the moment it is absolutely horrendous.

context_findings.summary: Birthday is tomorrow; he may do a bonus stream.
context_findings.quote: Guys, it's my birthday tomorrow… I'm not 30 yet, so I'm still alive and young, but soon.

context_findings.summary: Expresses frustration with repetitive or premature questions from chat, but enjoys streaming overall.
context_findings.quote: Sometimes I get very annoyed at chat when they just ask really stupid questions, but I do kinda really like streaming.

context_findings.summary: Believes 3D-platformer quality bar is low; a game that simply 'doesn't suck' can succeed.
context_findings.quote: If you just make a hack or make a game that doesn't suck, I think it's going to be popular.

biobak.summary: Biobak appears briefly in chat; no development tasks discussed.

zeina.summary: Zeina drops in after the paper-airplane progress; offers minor reactions but no new animation work this stream.

key_stories.title: Taming the Paper Plane
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants a believable paper-airplane ride. Initial equations made it spin endlessly or crash. By logging variables, capping pitch, adding sine-based torque and friction, and iterating live, he reached a stable swoop that lands near the target.
key_stories.challenge: Early physics caused infinite spins or loss of speed, breaking the intended flight path.
key_stories.process: Added gravity, sine(pitch) scaling, forward-velocity clamps, friction, and real-time logging; moved spawn for faster tests.
key_stories.outcome: Plane now performs an up-down swoop and roughly lands on the pyramid; final fine-tuning left.
key_stories.key_quote: You ever shot a real paper airplane? It's a volatile, chaotic system—I'm basically recreating that.

key_stories.title: The Vanishing First Frame
key_stories.summary: Rubber-band animation played one frame late, making the band appear suddenly. Kaze discovered Fast64’s smart-animation-range feature was trimming frame 0.
key_stories.challenge: Rubber band snapped visually because the initial frame wasn’t exported.
key_stories.process: Inspected Blender curves, printed animation indices, then added a dummy keyframe before start to force export.
key_stories.outcome: Rubber band now stretches and releases smoothly; will add sound later.
key_stories.key_quote: The first animation frame wasn't exporting—smart animation range cut it because there was no keyframe before it.

open_questions.context: Kaze says the hack is RSP-bottlenecked and F3DX3 plus triangle strips help, but details are sparse.
questions: What specific optimisations does F3DX3 provide over Fast3D?
How did you integrate it into the decomp?
What remaining performance ceilings exist on real hardware?

open_questions.context: Level currently called Course 14/Course 15/Handmade Heights; order may change.
questions: What will Course 14 finally be named and why?
How do the multi-biome areas tie into gameplay goals?
How do you decide course order this late in development?
What other Fast64 issues slow you down?
Are you considering contributing fixes or building custom exporters?
How does the pipeline differ between N64 and PC assets?

open_questions.context: Kaze debates separate accounts for the hack versus using his main channel.
questions: What’s the current plan for promoting Return to Yoshi’s Island?
Will there be official accounts or stick to Kaze’s?
How will each team member participate in outreach?

open_questions.context: Kaze hints at making a new 3D platformer in Unreal Engine 5, maybe custom engine.
questions: What core ideas or mechanics would carry over?
Why Unreal over Unity or a bespoke engine?
Will the current team transition to the new project?
